title: Sir Dave Ramsden, deputy Bank of England Governor: 'The world is becoming a more uncertain place to do business in'
text:
As the Bank of England rate-setters attempt to peer through the fog of Brexit, it’s handy that one of its most senior officials is used to low visibility and climbing mountains.

Sir Dave Ramsden, the Bank’s deputy Governor for markets and banking, once embarked on a traverse of the 4,000-metre high Mont Pelvoux in the French Alps, ice axes and all. After a speech in Inverness this year, he went over to Skye to take on the forbidding Cuillin Ridge. “The cloud level was completely down, so I had to navigate my way through," says the 55-year-old. "I’ve been there a few times, so I’m reasonably good at map reading and finding my way up and down safely.”

Can the Bank do the same? We’re almost tripping...
